active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the most effective pretexting tactic for targeting executives during travel (e.g., USB baiting at airports vs. fake hotel WiFi support). Provide real-world examples from cybersecurity reports and evaluate ethical boundaries in penetration testing.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Penetration Testing and Ethical Hacking. Generate 20 high-quality flashcards (5 per scaffolding layer) on 'Executive Travel Scenarios' using the exact topic hierarchy: Cybersecurity (Level 1) > Penetration Testing And Ethical Hacking (Level 2) > Social Engineering Testing (Level 3) > 008_Advanced Attack Techniques (Level 4) > Advanced Pretexting Scenarios (Level 5) > Executive Travel Scenarios (Level 6). Incorporate this completed research context: Executive travel risks include physical theft, digital surveillance (IMSI catchers, WiFi sniffing), USB baiting (infected USBs left in airports/hotels), BadUSB, rogue WiFi, hotel compromises. OpSec: preparation/vigilance/review. Sources: frameworks.securityalliance.org, cyber.gc.ca, vikingcloud.com, dni.gov. Use these learning objectives: [insert full list from JSON]. Structure via 4-layer scaffolding: [insert full scaffolding from JSON]. Active learning integration: Weave in prompts/activities into explanations (e.g., 'Discuss in peer teaching...'). Text-based concept map: Central 'Executive Travel Pretexting' → Threats (Physical Theft, USB Baiting, etc.) → OpSec Countermeasures → Pentest Steps → Integration with Social Engineering. Output EXACTLY in this flashcard schema for each: { 'layer': 'Layer 1 Foundation', 'bloom_level': 'REMEMBER', 'front': 'Question? A) D1 B) D2 C) Correct D) D3', 'back': { 'answer': '**Correct**', 'explanation': 'Rationale...', 'source': 'frameworks.securityalliance.org', 'active_learning_link': 'Tie to discussion prompt' } } Vary formats: 40% MCQ (w/ 3 distractors per protocol), 30% cloze, 30% scenario-based for APPLY/ANALYZE/CREATE. Ensure pedagogical progression, voter consensus (completeness on threats like USB Baiting), and university-style depth.
